p: Flooding is associated with surface and drinking water contamination from overflowing sewers, agricultural run-off, and degradation of infrastructure. Infrastructure degradation can disrupt public health and health care access [ 3, 4, 64]. Carnes et al. [ 4] cited a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention study that noted that gastroenteritis-associated deaths rose from approximately 7000 to more than 17,000 yearly over the past 8 years, with 83% of those deaths occurring in older adults ( > 65 years old). Indirect impacts of flooding that may have associated mortality but may not be attributed to climate change. These include exposures to mold [ 3] or other pathogens (such as Legionella) [ 64], injury from the flooding event, or failure to rescue from an overwhelmed health system during a flooding emergency [ 4].
